segment.source: File access permissions
segment.target: File access permissions

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Apps can access certain file system locations by default.
segment.target: Apps can access certain file system locations by default.

segment.source: Apps can also access additional locations through the file picker, or by declaring capabilities.
segment.target: Apps can also access additional locations through the file picker, or by declaring capabilities.

segment.source: The locations that all apps can access
segment.target: The locations that all apps can access

segment.source: When you create a new app, you can access the following file system locations by default:
segment.target: When you create a new app, you can access the following file system locations by default:

segment.source: Application install directory.
segment.target: Application install directory.

segment.source: The folder where your app is installed on the user’s system.
segment.target: The folder where your app is installed on the user’s system.

segment.source: There are two primary ways to access files and folders in your app’s install directory:
segment.target: There are two primary ways to access files and folders in your app’s install directory:

segment.source: You can retrieve a StorageFolder that represents your app's install directory, like this:
segment.target: You can retrieve a StorageFolder that represents your app's install directory, like this:

segment.source: You can then access files and folders in the directory using StorageFolder methods.
segment.target: You can then access files and folders in the directory using StorageFolder methods.

segment.source: In the example, this StorageFolder is stored in the variable.
segment.target: In the example, this StorageFolder is stored in the variable.

segment.source: You can learn more about working with your app package and install directory by downloading the App package information sample for Windows 8.1 and re-using its source code in your Windows 10 app.
segment.target: You can learn more about working with your app package and install directory by downloading the App package information sample for Windows 8.1 and re-using its source code in your Windows 10 app.

segment.source: You can retrieve a file directly from your app's install directory by using an app URI, like this:
segment.target: You can retrieve a file directly from your app's install directory by using an app URI, like this:

segment.source: When GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync completes, it returns a StorageFile that represents the file.txt file in the app's install directory ( in the example).
segment.target: When GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync completes, it returns a StorageFile that represents the file.txt file in the app's install directory ( in the example).

segment.source: The "ms-appx:///" prefix in the URI refers to the app's install directory.
segment.target: The "ms-appx:///" prefix in the URI refers to the app's install directory.

segment.source: You can learn more about using app URIs in How to use URIs to reference content.
segment.target: You can learn more about using app URIs in How to use URIs to reference content.

segment.source: In addition, and unlike other locations, you can also access files in your app install directory by using some Win32 and COM for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and some C/C++ Standard Library functions from Microsoft Visual Studio.
segment.target: In addition, and unlike other locations, you can also access files in your app install directory by using some Win32 and COM for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and some C/C++ Standard Library functions from Microsoft Visual Studio.

segment.source: The app's install directory is a read-only location.
segment.target: The app's install directory is a read-only location.

segment.source: You can’t gain access to the install directory through the file picker.
segment.target: You can’t gain access to the install directory through the file picker.

segment.source: Application data locations.
segment.target: Application data locations.

segment.source: The folders where your app can store data.
segment.target: The folders where your app can store data.

segment.source: These folders (local, roaming and temporary) are created when your app is installed.
segment.target: These folders (local, roaming and temporary) are created when your app is installed.

segment.source: There are two primary ways to access files and folders from your app’s data locations:
segment.target: There are two primary ways to access files and folders from your app’s data locations:

segment.source: Use ApplicationData properties to retrieve an app data folder.
segment.target: Use ApplicationData properties to retrieve an app data folder.

segment.source: For example, you can use ApplicationData.LocalFolder to retrieve a StorageFolder that represents your app's local folder like this:
segment.target: For example, you can use ApplicationData.LocalFolder to retrieve a StorageFolder that represents your app's local folder like this:

segment.source: If you want to access your app's roaming or temporary folder, use the RoamingFolder or TemporaryFolder property instead.
segment.target: If you want to access your app's roaming or temporary folder, use the RoamingFolder or TemporaryFolder property instead.

segment.source: After you retrieve a StorageFolder that represents an app data location, you can access files and folders in that location by using StorageFolder methods.
segment.target: After you retrieve a StorageFolder that represents an app data location, you can access files and folders in that location by using StorageFolder methods.

segment.source: In the example, these StorageFolder objects are stored in the variable.
segment.target: In the example, these StorageFolder objects are stored in the variable.

segment.source: You can learn more about using app data locations in Managing application data, and by downloading the Application data sample for Windows 8.1 and re-using its source code in your Windows 10 app.
segment.target: You can learn more about using app data locations in Managing application data, and by downloading the Application data sample for Windows 8.1 and re-using its source code in your Windows 10 app.

segment.source: For example, you can retrieve a file directly from your app's local folder by using an app URI, like this:
segment.target: For example, you can retrieve a file directly from your app's local folder by using an app URI, like this:

segment.source: When GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync completes, it returns a StorageFile that represents the file.txt file in the app's local folder ( in the example).
segment.target: When GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync completes, it returns a StorageFile that represents the file.txt file in the app's local folder ( in the example).

segment.source: The "ms-appdata:///local/" prefix in the URI refers to the app's local folder.
segment.target: The "ms-appdata:///local/" prefix in the URI refers to the app's local folder.

segment.source: To access files in the app's roaming or temporary folders use "ms-appdata:///roaming/" or "ms-appdata:///temporary/" instead.
segment.target: To access files in the app's roaming or temporary folders use "ms-appdata:///roaming/" or "ms-appdata:///temporary/" instead.

segment.source: You can learn more about using app URIs in How to load file resources.
segment.target: You can learn more about using app URIs in How to load file resources.

segment.source: In addition, and unlike other locations, you can also access files in your app data locations by using some Win32 and COM for UWP apps and some C/C++ Standard Library functions from Visual Studio.
segment.target: In addition, and unlike other locations, you can also access files in your app data locations by using some Win32 and COM for UWP apps and some C/C++ Standard Library functions from Visual Studio.

segment.source: You can’t access the local, roaming, or temporary folders through the file picker.
segment.target: You can’t access the local, roaming, or temporary folders through the file picker.

segment.source: Removable devices.
segment.target: Removable devices.

segment.source: Additionally, your app can access some of the files on connected devices by default.
segment.target: Additionally, your app can access some of the files on connected devices by default.

segment.source: This is an option if your app uses the AutoPlay extension to launch automatically when users connect a device, like a camera or USB thumb drive, to their system.
segment.target: This is an option if your app uses the AutoPlay extension to launch automatically when users connect a device, like a camera or USB thumb drive, to their system.

segment.source: The files your app can access are limited to specific file types that are specified via File Type Association declarations in your app manifest.
segment.target: The files your app can access are limited to specific file types that are specified via File Type Association declarations in your app manifest.

segment.source: Of course, you can also gain access to files and folders on a removable device by calling the file picker (using FileOpenPicker and FolderPicker) and letting the user pick files and folders for your app to access.
segment.target: Of course, you can also gain access to files and folders on a removable device by calling the file picker (using FileOpenPicker and FolderPicker) and letting the user pick files and folders for your app to access.

segment.source: Learn how to use the file picker in Open files and folders with a picker.
segment.target: Learn how to use the file picker in Open files and folders with a picker.

segment.source: Note For more info about accessing an SD card from a mobile app, see Access the SD card.
segment.target: Note For more info about accessing an SD card from a mobile app, see Access the SD card.

segment.source: Locations Windows Store apps can access
segment.target: Locations Windows Store apps can access

segment.source: User’s Downloads folder.
segment.target: User’s Downloads folder.

segment.source: The folder where downloaded files are saved by default.
segment.target: The folder where downloaded files are saved by default.

segment.source: By default, your app can only access files and folders in the user's Downloads folder that your app created.
segment.target: By default, your app can only access files and folders in the user's Downloads folder that your app created.

segment.source: However, you can gain access to files and folders in the user's Downloads folder by calling a file picker (FileOpenPicker or FolderPicker) so that users can navigate and pick files or folders for your app to access.
segment.target: However, you can gain access to files and folders in the user's Downloads folder by calling a file picker (FileOpenPicker or FolderPicker) so that users can navigate and pick files or folders for your app to access.

segment.source: You can create a file in the user's Downloads folder like this:
segment.target: You can create a file in the user's Downloads folder like this:

segment.source: DownloadsFolder.CreateFileAsync is overloaded so that you can specify what the system should do if there is already an existing file in the Downloads folder that has the same name.
segment.target: DownloadsFolder.CreateFileAsync is overloaded so that you can specify what the system should do if there is already an existing file in the Downloads folder that has the same name.

segment.source: When these methods complete, they return a StorageFile that represents the file that was created.
segment.target: When these methods complete, they return a StorageFile that represents the file that was created.

segment.source: This file is called in the example.
segment.target: This file is called in the example.

segment.source: You can create a subfolder in the user's Downloads folder like this:
segment.target: You can create a subfolder in the user's Downloads folder like this:

segment.source: DownloadsFolder.CreateFolderAsync is overloaded so that you can specify what the system should do if there is already an existing subfolder in the Downloads folder that has the same name.
segment.target: DownloadsFolder.CreateFolderAsync is overloaded so that you can specify what the system should do if there is already an existing subfolder in the Downloads folder that has the same name.

segment.source: When these methods complete, they return a StorageFolder that represents the subfolder that was created.
segment.target: When these methods complete, they return a StorageFolder that represents the subfolder that was created.

segment.source: This file is called in the example.
segment.target: This file is called in the example.

segment.source: If you create a file or folder in the Downloads folder, we recommend that you add that item to your app's FutureAccessList so that your app can readily access that item in the future.
segment.target: If you create a file or folder in the Downloads folder, we recommend that you add that item to your app's FutureAccessList so that your app can readily access that item in the future.

segment.source: Accessing additional locations
segment.target: Accessing additional locations

segment.source: In addition to the default locations, an app can access additional files and folders by declaring capabilities in the app manifest (see App capability declarations), or by calling a file picker to let the user pick files and folders for the app to access (see Open files and folders with a picker).
segment.target: In addition to the default locations, an app can access additional files and folders by declaring capabilities in the app manifest (see App capability declarations), or by calling a file picker to let the user pick files and folders for the app to access (see Open files and folders with a picker).

segment.source: The following table lists additional locations that you can access by declaring a capability (or capabilities) and using the associated Windows.Storage API:
segment.target: The following table lists additional locations that you can access by declaring a capability (or capabilities) and using the associated Windows.Storage API:

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: Capability
segment.target: Capability

segment.source: Windows.Storage API
segment.target: Windows.Storage API

segment.source: Documents
segment.target: Documents

segment.source: DocumentsLibrary
segment.target: DocumentsLibrary

segment.source: Note: You must add File Type Associations to your app manifest that declare specific file types that your app can access in this location.
segment.target: Note: You must add File Type Associations to your app manifest that declare specific file types that your app can access in this location.

segment.source: Use this capability if your app:
segment.target: Use this capability if your app:

segment.source: - Facilitates cross-platform offline access to specific OneDrive content using valid OneDrive URLs or Resource IDs
segment.target: - Facilitates cross-platform offline access to specific OneDrive content using valid OneDrive URLs or Resource IDs

segment.source: - Saves open files to the user’s OneDrive automatically while offline
segment.target: - Saves open files to the user’s OneDrive automatically while offline

segment.source: KnownFolders.DocumentsLibrary
segment.target: KnownFolders.DocumentsLibrary

segment.source: Music
segment.target: Music

segment.source: MusicLibrary
segment.target: MusicLibrary

segment.source: Also see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.
segment.target: Also see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.

segment.source: KnownFolders.MusicLibrary
segment.target: KnownFolders.MusicLibrary

segment.source: Pictures
segment.target: Pictures

segment.source: PicturesLibrary
segment.target: PicturesLibrary

segment.source: Also see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.
segment.target: Also see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.

segment.source: KnownFolders.PicturesLibrary
segment.target: KnownFolders.PicturesLibrary

segment.source: Videos
segment.target: Videos

segment.source: VideosLibrary
segment.target: VideosLibrary

segment.source: Also see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.
segment.target: Also see Files and folders in the Music, Pictures, and Videos libraries.

segment.source: KnownFolders.VideosLibrary
segment.target: KnownFolders.VideosLibrary

segment.source: Removable devices
segment.target: Removable devices

segment.source: RemovableDevices
segment.target: RemovableDevices

segment.source: Note You must add File Type Associations to your app manifest that declare specific file types that your app can access in this location.
segment.target: Note You must add File Type Associations to your app manifest that declare specific file types that your app can access in this location.

segment.source: Also see Access the SD card.
segment.target: Also see Access the SD card.

segment.source: KnownFolders.RemovableDevices
segment.target: KnownFolders.RemovableDevices

segment.source: Homegroup libraries
segment.target: Homegroup libraries

segment.source: At least one of the following capabilities is needed.
segment.target: At least one of the following capabilities is needed.

segment.source: - MusicLibrary
segment.target: - MusicLibrary

segment.source: - PicturesLibrary
segment.target: - PicturesLibrary

segment.source: - VideosLibrary
segment.target: - VideosLibrary

segment.source: KnownFolders.HomeGroup
segment.target: KnownFolders.HomeGroup

segment.source: Media server devices (DLNA)
segment.target: Media server devices (DLNA)

segment.source: At least one of the following capabilities is needed.
segment.target: At least one of the following capabilities is needed.

segment.source: - MusicLibrary
segment.target: - MusicLibrary

segment.source: - PicturesLibrary
segment.target: - PicturesLibrary

segment.source: - VideosLibrary
segment.target: - VideosLibrary

segment.source: KnownFolders.MediaServerDevices
segment.target: KnownFolders.MediaServerDevices

segment.source: Universal Naming Convention (UNC) folders
segment.target: Universal Naming Convention (UNC) folders

segment.source: A combination of the following capabilities is needed.
segment.target: A combination of the following capabilities is needed.

segment.source: The home and work networks capability:
segment.target: The home and work networks capability:

segment.source: - PrivateNetworkClientServer
segment.target: - PrivateNetworkClientServer

segment.source: And at least one internet and public networks capability:
segment.target: And at least one internet and public networks capability:

segment.source: - InternetClient
segment.target: - InternetClient

segment.source: - InternetClientServer
segment.target: - InternetClientServer

segment.source: And, if applicable, the domain credentials capability:
segment.target: And, if applicable, the domain credentials capability:

segment.source: - EnterpriseAuthentication
segment.target: - EnterpriseAuthentication

segment.source: Note: You must add File Type Associations to your app manifest that declare specific file types that your app can access in this location.
segment.target: Note: You must add File Type Associations to your app manifest that declare specific file types that your app can access in this location.

segment.source: Retrieve a folder using:
segment.target: Retrieve a folder using:

segment.source: StorageFolder.GetFolderFromPathAsync
segment.target: StorageFolder.GetFolderFromPathAsync

segment.source: Retrieve a file using:
segment.target: Retrieve a file using:

segment.source: StorageFile.GetFileFromPathAsync
segment.target: StorageFile.GetFileFromPathAsync
